question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
Find the greatest common divisor of 957 and 1537.
inference:
Using the Euclidean Algorithm:
\begin{enumerate}
\item Divide 1537 by 957:
$1537 = 1 \times 957 + 580$
\item Divide 957 by 580:
$957 = 1 \times 580 + 377$
\item Divide 580 by 377:
$580 = 1 \times 377 + 203$
\item Divide 377 by 203:
$377 = 1 \times 203 + 174$
\item Divide 203 by 174:
$203 = 1 \times 174 + 29$
\item Divide 174 by 29:
$174 = 6 \times 29 + 0$
\end{enumerate}
The last non-zero remainder is 29.

Final Answer: $\boxed{29}$. I hope it is correct.
ground_truth:
Observing that neither $957$ nor $1537$ can be divided by $2,$ $3,$ $5,$ or $7,$ we turn to the Euclidean algorithm. We get \begin{align*}
\text{gcd}(957,1537) &= \text{gcd}(957, 1537 - 957) \\
&= \text{gcd}(957,580) \\
&= \text{gcd}(580, 957 -580) \\
&= \text{gcd}(580,377) \\
&= \text{gcd}(377,580-377) \\
&= \text{gcd}(377,203) \\
&= \text{gcd}(203,174) \\
&= \text{gcd}(174,203-174) \\
&= \text{gcd}(174,29) \\
&= \boxed{29}.
\end{align*}Remark: Note that we could have computed $\text{gcd}(957,580)$ more quickly by observing that  \[
\text{957 is divisible by neither 2 nor 5}\]\[ \implies \text{gcd}(957,580)=\text{gcd}(957,58).
\]The greatest common divisor of 957 and 58 can be calculated using the Euclidean algorithm in one step: long division gives $957 \div 58 = 16\text{ remainder }29$.

The Euclidean Algorithm finds the greatest common divisor (GCD) of two integers.  The process is correctly shown. The final non-zero remainder is the GCD.

$\boxed{29}$
ground_truth:
Observing that neither $957$ nor $1537$ can be divided by $2,$ $3,$ $5,$ or $7,$ we turn to the Euclidean algorithm. We get \begin{align*}
\text{gcd}(957,1537) &= \text{gcd}(957, 1537 - 957) \\
&= \text{gcd}(957,580) \\
&= \text{gcd}(580, 957 -580) \\
&= \text{gcd}(580,377) \\
&= \text{gcd}(377,580-377) \\
&= \text{gcd}(377,203) \\
&= \text{gcd}(203,174) \\
&= \text{gcd}(174,203-174) \\
&= \text{gcd}(174,29) \\
&= \boxed{29}.
\end{align*}Remark: Note that we could have computed $\text{gcd}(957,580)$ more quickly by observing that  \[
\text{957 is divisible by neither 2 nor 5}\]\[ \implies \text{gcd}(957,580)=\text{gcd}(957,58).
\]The greatest common divisor of 957 and 58 can be calculated using the Euclidean algorithm in one step: long division gives $957 \div 58 = 16\text{ remainder }29$.
